awd_titl_txt: The Economic and Social Impacts of New Infrastructural Development in Rural Areas
awd_abstract_narration:
Road construction offers new economic and social opportunities for people, and opens, or improves, access to new places. In the U.S. and around the world, rural people often aggressively lobby local and federal governments for new or improved roads, especially in rural areas with high poverty due to limited economic opportunities, poor access to education and other social services, and where infrastructure improvements are rare. In advocating for road construction and improvement, local people imagine first and foremost, improved economic opportunities, whether due to ease of transportation to jobs, transporting goods out for sale, the arrival of new jobs, or through opportunities for new entrepreneurial activity in conjunction with the new road. People living near a new road may also anticipate easier communication and visiting with extended family and distant friends or colleagues, and improved access to health care, schools and other social services. However, people do not always anticipate some of the problems that new roads can bring, such as increased crime and drug activity due to easier access and fast escape from communities, or increases in outsider purchase of land and property that may drive up taxes for local people. In some cases, new roads can lead to shared local resources that people value (such as ocean, lake, forest or pasture access) becoming privatized, which consequently negatively impacts local people's ability to make a living. Through an intensive study of communities living near a new road built in 2016 in an impoverished rural community, Dr. Cliggett, an anthropologist at the University of Kentucky, will investigate how new roads can best benefit local people and identify ways to avoid the negative aspects of this kind of infrastructure development. Project findings will also be presented to non-academic audiences, improving efforts to communicate science to the public. The project would train graduate students in methods of scientifically-grounded and empirical data collection.

The research will be conducted in rural Zambia where a recent World Bank funded project facilitated the construction of a new road along the Kariba Lake shoreline (part of the Zambezi River valley), in a remote region, difficult to access and known for its poverty. Dr. Cliggett and her research team, which includes US students, will investigate the variety of impacts from the road in two communities at opposite ends this new transportation corridor. It is selected because it is an ideal site for examining long-term change through infrastructural development. These two communities were previously part of one large village with dense family ties and interdependent rural livelihoods, but were separated in 1958 when the Kariba Dam was built on the Zambezi river. Despite the physical distance of the two villages (approximately 130 miles), the communities remain socially connected through kinship and local political organizations. The new road allows direct transportation routes (approximately 4 hours) between these two communities for the first time since 1958. Consequently, the new road is likely to facilitate a resurgence of social networks, family reintegration and political activity, in addition to new economic opportunities. The research team will survey women, men and local political leaders in the two communities about how their economic activities have changed since the road was built, changes in their social connections with relatives and friends living at opposite ends of the road, and the impacts of outsiders gaining access to lakeshore and other lands near the road. In addition to survey interviews, the research team will use digital mapping tools to identify places of economic activity and places where land is being purchased by outsiders. The research team will use baseline information from a long-term research project (Gwembe Tonga Research Project, started in 1958) in these communities to assess how local economies, social networks, and privatization of land have changed since the road was built. This research will allow Dr. Cliggett and her research team to make policy recommendations that can enhance the benefits of this kind of new infrastructure, while minimizing the negative impacts associated with new roads or other similar infrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied communities living near a new road built in 2016 in an impoverished rural community. It considered how new roads can best benefit local people and how negative impacts of this kind of development can emerge unless such projects are implemented with clear and forward-looking attention to affected communities.

Dr. Cliggett, an anthropologist at the University of Kentucky, conducted field research in Zambia (and oversaw US students) during three field seasons (2018 (2 months), 2019 (3 months), 2023 (3 months)).  During field visits Dr. Cliggett and her students conducted in-depth ethnographic research while living with families in the focal communities. The team collected data on three aspects of life in two communities-  each at one end of the new road.  The research focused on: 1) how people's livelihoods have changed since the road was build, 2) how local environments (and ecosystems) have changed in relation to the road, and 3) how people have used the road to reconnect with relatives who have been difficult to visit for the past sixty years, when the two communities constituted one village. These two communities were previously part of one large village with dense family ties and interdependent rural livelihoods but were separated in 1958 when the Kariba Dam was built on the Zambezi River.  These communities have been part of a long-term study of continuity and change, and the impacts of development in rural places.

The research team used survey interviews of women and men and local leaders to understand the variety of ways life has changed for their families and the community more broadly since the road was built.  The research team also used digital mapping tools to identify where economic activity has grown and changed along the road, and where ecosystems show signs of change, particularly forest clearing and industrial activities.

This research provides insight for the social sciences, development efforts and the social components of infrastructure-planning by showing how communities living at the sites of new infrastructure development are impacted by such change. Specifically, the research shows how livelihoods change and respond to a new road built in their region, and how the environment changes (often for the worst) in areas with road development. The project also highlights the mechanisms by which non-local actors gain control of local resources to the detriment of local communities. The data from this project support political ecological theories about the ways "development" often disenfranchises local communities and unravels natural resource-based livelihoods.

The key findings from the research include:

1. The road helped to generate economic growth in the study communities and along the road corridor.

2. The road triggered rapid growth in livelihoods dependent on natural resource extraction, and consequent environmental change.

3. The road facilitates outsiders illegally acquiring local lands for private investment which excludes local residents from accessing communal lands (where they fished, farmed and harvested natural resources).

4. The road does not appear to enhance social connections between the two focal communities at each end of the road, nor increase in tensions or conflicts, which the research team also thought might occur.

Altogether, these findings suggest that new infrastructure can have positive benefits for local communities in their vicinity. However, planners must consider other possible outcomes from such infrastructure (such as rapid environmental change), and work with local communities to identify ways to minimize these impacts. Strategies for minimization of negative impacts might be including social-economic development in road projects such as 1) sustainable livelihood programs that provide sufficient inputs and support over time, to attract local populations and dissuade them from activities contributing to rapid environmental change; 2) plan ahead for the likelihood of outsiders seeking land and implement systems that ensure local communities as a collective are primary decision makers and beneficiaries of local projects. For example: establish requirements (and systems of accountability) that all residents participate in any discussions and decisions about new industrial/ economic projects. Additionally, ensure that all residents (not just a few leaders) hold significant ownership in the industry such that a portion of profits come to each adult (male and female) in a community.

Outcomes beyond the research findings:  

1. Publications, white papers, and presentations: two academic articles, one white paper for a local land rights organization, three academic conference presentations, multiple community meetings with both study communities during each field visit to share current findings, one presentation to the University of Zambia faculty.

2. Student training: six US anthropology students (5 PhD, 1 bachelor's degree) received field methods training in challenging rural field settings.

3. Establishing enduring academic exchange with faculty at the University of Zambia: The research project facilitated collaborative relationships (including an MOU between the University of Kentucky and UNZA) with colleagues at the University of Zambia, which will endure beyond the life of the project.
